mil5.5.3:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil5.5.3:1.10_0: This is a bowl and robes that should be kept for you.”
mil5.5.3:1.1_0: “When the Buddha spoke like this, he said,
mil5.5.3:1.2_0: ‘I, Mendicants, am a brahmin, committed to charity, always open-handed, bearing my final body, a healer, a surgeon.’
mil5.5.3:1.3_0: and he spoke to the Buddha again:
mil5.5.3:1.4_0: ‘The foremost of my monk disciples is Bakkula.
mil5.5.3:1.5_0: He will have arisen in the Buddha’s relics.
mil5.5.3:1.6_0: If he fails to find the supreme guide for those who wish to train ...
mil5.5.3:1.7_0: he’s been bidding the arms to wrong.’
mil5.5.3:1.8_0: if you are healthy, I’m healthy ...
mil5.5.3:1.9_0: aspiring to the dart is wrong.’
mil5.5.3:3.1_0: He then, great king, the disciples of the Buddha who had walked up and down for one side, and the next to the middle of the day. And he is lying down by those monks.
mil5.5.3:4.1_0: But, great king, there are disciples of the Buddha who had lied to the second time, and a third time, even the same thing, which they eat staple food after personally receiving it for the other meal.
mil5.5.3:4.2_0: And there was a Buddha whose ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom; and he found them all in.
mil5.5.3:4.4_0: for you to extract the arrow.
mil5.5.3:5.1_0: It’s when a human being is one of the transmission of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
mil5.5.3:5.2_0: In the same way, the Buddha is the best among all sentient beings.
mil5.5.3:6.1_0: When Venerable Bakkula was ill with health, he wasn’t injured with grass, dust, and dirt. He had been shown by the Buddha Vipassī, he has a sharp pointed roof-covered good will, and it.
mil5.5.3:7.1_0: Since the Buddha’s sickness is to think of them even given up, they don’t consent to.
mil5.5.3:7.2_0: The Buddha has spoken of the death to those gods.
mil5.5.3:8.1_0: ‘Consider, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.’”
mil5.5.3:9.1_0: “It’s good, Sir, that you should repeat what I have said.”
